titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Bathed at the bottom of the Common, this morning before breakfast.— The weather being again extremely warm, I pass’d the remainder of the day at home untill near sun-set— Arranging papers in the forenoon; reading the Bacchides of Plautus, after dinner— The plot depends on the mistakes occasioned by twin-sisters— A cunning scoundrel slave, who cheats an old-man for the benefit of his son, as usual.— A vain glorious soldier again— The varieties are, a Pedagogue or School-Master, who complains bitterly of the degeneracy of the times, and the degradation of his Office— And two old-men wheedled by the two girls, till they imitate the excesses of their sons— Walk in the Mall; where I met Mr: Emerson and Mr: Phillips— Found Mr: Hall, when I came home— Walk with Mrs: Adams.

2. Called this morning at Mr: Parsons’s Office, but he was out of town. The weather turn’d extremely cold, and this afternoon we had quite a north-east storm— I went out to Quincy nevertheless— Found my mother very ill— My father too has been unwell, and appears not to be perfectly recovered— I bathed this morning, at the bottom of the Common— Began to read the Mostellaria of Plautus but had not time to finish it

3. Heard Mr: Williams of Weymouth, who dined with us— His afternoon Sermon was upon good and bad bargains— Read the last four of the Provincial letters, and continued to write upon the life of Pascal. It is a very amusing occupation— B. Beale junr: told me of Mr: King’s arrival at New-York 30. ulto: Dr: Welsh and his lady came out this afternoon, from Boston, and return’d at Night— He had seen Mrs: Adams, since noon— She was well, and had walk’d to Mrs: Gray’s in Tremont Street.

4. Independence Day. I return’d to Boston early this morning; and on my arrival received from the countenance, and mouth of Mr: Shaw the news, that I have a second child— A Son— Born at 3 o’clock this morning— The mother and child are both as well as I could hope. For this new blessing, I desire to offer my humblest gratitude to the throne of Heaven— Mrs: Adams was taken ill between 7 and 8 last Evening. Sent for Dr: Welsh about 11.— He had not long been returned from Quincy. I went to hear the anniversary Oration, which was delivered by Mr: W. Sullivan. The prayer by Mr: Baldwin, the Chaplain to the House of Representatives— In the afternoon I called at Mr: Parsons’s Office, and saw him.— Took one turn in the Mall, where there was as usual a great crowd of people. Evening at home.

5. Mrs: Adams is as well as her condition admits— The child has a bad cold— Mr: T. Thomas called on me this Morning— At Judge Dawes’s Office, and Judge Davis’s— To meet on the questions respecting the Hopkins legacy— The former could not attend this day.— We agreed to meet next Friday at 10 o’clock in the Morning. The Court of Common Pleas meet this day. At noon we had the semi-annual meeting of the Directors of Neponsit Bridge, and settled the Treasurer’s Accounts.— I read this afternoon the remainder of Plautus’s Mostellaria, and four acts of the Menaechmei— The Retour Imprevu of Regnard is taken from the former, and his Menechmes from the latter— In the Mostellaria, a slave passes two deceptions upon an old man, who is returning home after a long absence— He makes him believe his house is haunted, and that his son has purchased another for him— Regnard has adopted and improved upon both incidents.

6. Mrs: Adams more unwell this day than before; and this evening suddenly and for some time excessively ill.— I found her so on returning from the club at Mr: Emerson’s— I met Dr: Warren this morning; who was going out to Quincy, to see my mother— Letters from my brother— The post-office has made free with one I sent him some time since— I finished reading the Menaechmei of Plautus and began the Miles Gloriosus— Shakespear’s Comedy of Errors, is taken closely, with respect to the incidents from the Menaechmei— He has however added the second pair of twins, the Dromio’s, as well as the characters and story of the parents to the Antipholis’s.— Child weighs 6 1/2 lb.

7. Mrs Adams, this day better; but still very feeble— Attended at the District Court, which is sitting. In the afternoon, finished the Miles Gloriosus, and read 2. Acts of the Mercator, of Plautus— The soldier is egregiously duped; but his character is dull and foolish in extreme— There is some resemblance between him and Shakespear’s Parolles— But the latter is much more amusing.— Walk’d in the Mall this Evening.— Read to Mrs: Adams Shenstone’s Schoolmistress and Johnson’s London—from Dodsley’s collection of poems.

8. Met judge Dawes and Judge Davis, at the office of the former, to consider the questions from the Trustees of the Hopkins donation— We examined the decree in Chancery, and agreed upon our Answers. Received a letter from Mr: King, inclosing two, from Lord and Lady Carysfort— In the afternoon read the last three acts of Miles Gloriosus Mercator, and the first two of Pseudolus— The Mercator is one of the most indifferent of Plautus’s Comedies— Tis an old man, in love with his son’s mistress.— I took a turn in the Mall, but the heat was so excessive I could walk no longer— In the evening, read to Mrs: Adams, Greene’s poem upon the Spleen, which is very pretty.

9. The warmest day of the Season. My Thermometer at 92. entirely in the shade.— Mrs: Otis called to pay Mrs: Adams a visit— Mr: Shaw went out to Quincy with Mr: Gardner.— Dexter came in for me; but I concluded not to go out— Finished Plautus’s Pseudolus this afternoon and read two acts of his Poenulus.— I once read the Pseudolus with Mr: Dumas, in the year 1783. But I recollected only one passage of the play; where the cook tells Ballio that Jupiter sups every night upon the vapours from his Cooking; and on Ballio’s asking him what Jupiter does when he is out of employ, the Cook answers, He goes to bed without supper— It is difficult to account for the impression which a particular passage makes upon the memory more than all others— There are an hundred witticisms in this Comedy, as good as this, which upon this perusal are as new to me, as if I had never read it— But this diverted me so much at the first reading that it has never since slip’d from my memory. The whole play amused me very much at the time— But the traces of it are all gone— Cicero admires the wit of Pseudolus— But it is one of the poet’s most indecent works— And there is a coarseness in the humour, which never would be tolerated in modern writer’s.— Walk’d this evening with Caroline, in the Mall.

10. Fore-part of the day warm as yesterday; about 2. in the afternoon, a slight thunder-shower with a very little rain changed the atmosphere, which in the evening became quite cool. Mrs: Adams, who ventured from her bed-room into another chamber, had a short but very severe attack similar to that of last Wednesday. She soon recovered, and for the remainder of the day was as well as before. Heard Dr: Howard in the Morning, and Mr: Emerson, this afternoon— Read two Sermons of Tillotson, 4th: vol: on suffering for Christ’s sake— Writing, a large part of the day— Walk in the Mall with Caroline, after Sunset.

11. I enter this day upon my thirty-seventh year, with sorrow to think how long I have lived, and to how little purpose— Bathed this morning before breakfast— Mr: Shaw returned from Quincy— Wrote a little this forenoon. At 4. this afternoon attended the annual parish-meeting, at Mr: Emerson’s.— Finished reading the Poenulus of Plautus. It is principally remarkable for a few lines of the Carthaginian language, spoken by Hanno the Carthaginian, at the opening of the 5th: Act— They are said to be the only specimen of that language extant— They bear a great resemblance to the Phoenician languages, and of course to the Hebrew. In other respects this Comedy is like the rest— Two courtezans discovered to be citizens, and an old pimp duped by a cunning slave. Walk’d alone in the Mall.

12. I have bathed at the bottom of the Common, yesterday and this morning before breakfast. Attended the Court of Common Pleas. Walk this Evening in the Mall, with Caroline— Just after we
returned home, there was a thunder shower, for about an hour— I read the Persa of Plautus:—the Amours of a Slave, and a pimp cheated— Mr: Smith called upon me this morning.

13. Went, with Caroline and George, to Quincy, where we pass’d the day. Found my mother, a little but not much better, than when I saw her last. Mrs: Cranch there after dinner.— We return’d to Boston at Night. Club at Mr: Freeman’s— Finished the first draught of my translation of Juvenal’s 7th: Satire, which has lain upon my hands unfinished, more than two years.

14. Attended the Court of Common Pleas this forenoon. Went out to Roxbury, Jamaica-Plains, and dined with Mr: Boylston— Mr: David Greene & his son; Mr: Gray, the Minister of that Parish Mr: Durant Mr: H. Brimmer, a Mr: Greenough, were the company— I return’d to town early in the Evening— Walk’d about an hour in the Mall— This morning, before breakfast, I bathed from a wharf behind the almshouse, a place mentioned last evening by Dr: Dexter, as much more convenient than that at the bottom of the common—and so I really found it.

15. Rain, a great part of the last Night, and this morning. I could not bathe. At the Court of Common Pleas, this forenoon— Read this afternoon Plautus’s Rudens— A Shipwreck. A casket— A Courtezan found to be daughter of an Athenian Citizen, and the old pimp to be fleeced.— Walk’d in the Mall— Read to the Ladies, about half an hour.

16. Called upon Mr: Emerson this morning, to inform him of my intention to have my child baptized to-morrow— Subscribed the declaration customary on this occasion— Attended a few minutes at the Court of Common-Pleas— Mr: Boylston called upon me— This afternoon I read the Stichus, of Plautus; one of the short plays— Two married women whose husbands have been long absent, and whose father urges them to marry again— The husbands however return home— There is a hungry parasite, who is deceived and a slave who is indulged with a treat— I also read some of Rousseau’s letters.

17. Unwell this morning; and a great part of the day— Heard a young Mr: Lincoln this Morning; and Mr: Emerson this afternoon. He baptized my child, by the name of John— I read two Sermons of Tillotson. The 68th: and 69th.— Good men Strangers and sojourners on Earth.— Walk’d morning & evening. We had several Thunder-Showers from 2 this afternoon, untill 9. in the Evening.

18. Attended at 11. this morning at the Academy’s room in the State-House, a meeting of the Trustees of the Hopkins Charity— The Committee on President Willard’s questions, made their report which was accepted— Upon which the meeting was dissolved— In the afternoon, I read the Trinummus of Plautus. The moral is better than in most of the others— It contains the model of a faithful friend— But even he to fulfill his obligations of fidelity, has recourse to fraud and imposture— From the anxiety manifested to give a young woman a portion, when her lover is willing to take her without one; it should seem it was held disgraceful to marry a female without it. The son, without authority sells his father’s house in his absence—and the poet, says he possess’d such a right by law— I amused myself with the Second Satire of Juvenal.

19. Coll: Humphreys, called on me this forenoon, and told me, Mr: Le Ray de Chaumont was in town with Mr: G. Morris— I paid them a visit, and went with Caroline to see Mr: & Mrs: Lear, but found none of them. Past the remainder of the day at home, excepting my customary morning and Evening, walks. This afternoon I read the Truculentus and the fragments of Plautus, and have thus gone through this author. I likewise read in the 22d: Volume of Lessing, his life of Plautus. The Truculentus is a struggle
between three lovers, for a Courtezan who values them exactly in proportion to their respective liberality; this play is among the incomplete pieces, much of which is lost. But is mentioned with approbation, by Cicero, together with the Pseudolus.— The general character of these plays is that they bear too close a resemblance together— Their greatest value arises from the representation of domestic manners they exhibit, and even in this respect I know not how much dependence can be placed upon them— The manners of the theatre differ in all Countries, most essentially from the manners of real life; and in this case most of the plays of Plautus are translated from the greeks— The characters are not much discriminated— An old dupe, a young spendthrift, a vixen wife, a tippling bawd, a scoundrel pimp, a swindling slave, a famish’d parasite, a hired impostor, and a braggart soldier, and a courtezan these ten personages constitute the whole of Plautus’s dramatis personae— His twenty plays now extant, as well as the six of Terence, are only varieties in the adventures natural to such persons. The incidents, the wit and the humour all turn upon the situations and relations of such beings. The range of human life is therefore extremely partial and confined. The wit is sometimes excellent, often vulgar— The moral occasionally good, and generally very bad— They are a mine of dramatic treasure, but the metal is buried in a heap of alloy.

20. Mr: Morris and Mr: Chaumont called on me this forenoon. As did a Captain Groves, with a project for discovering the longitude, by an observation of Jupiter’s Satellites— His invention is an instrument similar to that of Halley’s Quadrant, with a concave reflecting mirror, to bring the object upon the horizon, to observe it in spite of the ship’s motion— He has one or two other projects, with which he proposes going to Europe; for he can find here neither encouragement, nor an optician to make his instrument— I read this afternoon in Lessing’s works vol: 22. and 23. The letter to him against the Captives of Plautus, and his defence of that play— He persists to the last in the opinion, that it is the best Comedy ever brought upon any Stage— I think it the best of the plays of lautus.— In the Evening, club at Dr: Kirkland’s, which was thinly attended— Returning from club Dr: Elliot told me there had been in 1792 or 1793 a vote of Congress, that a copy of the Journals should be given to the Historical Society. But that they had not received them for several years— I promised to call for them, when I go on to Washington. He also told me Dr: Mitchell had written him, that a gentleman at the Southward, had a valuable manuscript which he had intended giving to the same Society. But he had been so much abused in the newspapers, here, he supposed nothing from him would be acceptable— Mitchell did not say who the gentleman was.

21. Mrs: Adams was very ill the greatest part of this day, and all the Evening— Mrs: Cranch here this morning. I called with Caroline, to see Mr: and Mrs: Humphreys, at Mrs: Whitwell’s, but they were abroad— This afternoon I took up the 6th: Volume of Montaigne, whom I drop’d about a month ago, to read Plautus. Began this forenoon a course of reading on American History, to which I purpose to devote two hours a day— Began with Winterbotham’s View of the United States.

22. Continued reading Winterbotham in the morning, and Montaigne, of whom I finished the 6th: volume, in the afternoon— Walk’d at the beginning of the Evening; Mrs: Adams is better. Congress is called together the 15th: of October— I endeavour to employ as much of my time as possible in study, to escape from Reflections and prospects, under which I cannot choose but feel impatient and worse.

23. Heavy rains in the Night; so that I did not go out in the morning— Forenoon at home— Principally reading, the life of Columbus— In the Afternoon began the 7th: volume of Montaigne. Went out to Quincy, with Mr: Dexter— Found my mother convalescent, and Louisa Smith very unwell.

24. Bathed between 5 and 6 this morning, at Mr: Black’s wharf— Heard Mr: Whitney— My Uncle Adams was with us at dinner.— Finished the sketch of Pascal’s life; and read some letters in the 3d: volume of Made: de Sevigné— Evening in conversation with my father.

25. Very warm night and copious showers— Bathed this morning before breakfast— Returned to Boston, in the forenoon— Received a letter from Mr: Kinnaird, introducing a Mr: King, at whose lodgings I called. Spent the afternoon, in reading Voltaire’s correspondence.

26. Bathed, from the wharf at Barton’s point, between 5 and 6 this morning; then walk’d an hour.— Finish’d reading the life of Columbus— In the afternoon, read La Harpe against Shakespear.— Walk’d in the Mall, with George— The dog days commence this day, and the weather is conformable.

27. Bathed at 5 this morning— And walk’d afterwards— Mr: King called on me this forenoon. Read in Winterbotham; and this afternoon in Montaigne’s 7th: volume— His Essays are divided into Books and Chapters; one knows not why— For there is no connection between his subjects; and often very little between the title of a Chapter and its Contents. For instance I read this afternoon the Chapter on the resemblance of children to their parents—which is in fact a violent philippic against physicians. a concentration of every thing that has been or can be said against the profession— I also met this afternoon what I take to be the root of Rochefoucault’s famous maxim concerning our enjoyment of the misfortunes of our friends— Club this evening at Mr: Smith’s. Thin— Dr: Prince there.

28. George with me last Night— Rained the greatest part of this day. Bathed early this morning, notwithstanding— Read further in Winterbotham; and this afternoon in Montaigne. Walk’d in the Mall at the commencement of the Evening.

29. Bathed at about 6 this morning— Went by invitation of the Select-men, on their annual party to Deer Island. Between 8 and 9 in the morning, we embarked, and reached the island at about 11. We went in the Castle barge, over to Point-Shirley, and Saw the salt-works Mr: Sturges is erecting there— We dined, and returned in manner similar to the former parties of the same kind; excepting that this time we got ashore for about a quarter of an hour; and one of the party lost his hat. We landed on the wharf at eight in the evening— On coming home, I found Mrs: Adams unwell, with a head-ache. General Pinckney and Coll: Humphreys, were of the party; and Messrs: King and Roper—

30. Mr: Sigourney called on me this morning— Mrs: Adams rode out, the first time since her confinement— No carriage came in from Quincy— I read in Winterbotham before dinner, but did not find time to write. In the afternoon finish’d the Chapter of Montaigne, on certain verses of Virgil, and the 7th: volume. The verses of Virgil, are those in which Venus obtains of Vulcan to forge arms for AEneas; but it is an excursive dissertation upon the physical connection of the two sexes, and all the author’s own experience on the subject. I bathed this evening, just at Dusk, and walk’d in the Mall, untill near 9.

31. Heard Mr: Ware of Hingham— Walk with Caroline in the Mall this Evening. Weather warm to excess.— Read the 69th: Sermon of Tillotson— The presence of the Messias the glory of the Second Temple—and the 70th.— Christ the only mediator between God and Man.

Day. Rise between 5 and 6. Bathe and walk about two hours— Read or amuse myself with George untill 9. Breakfast— At Market— Read or write untill 2. p.m. Dine— Read again untill Sunset— Walk an hour. Lounge away the time untill 10.
